It had no where to go but up, the pilot for Timeless was one of the worst network pilots I had seen in years (and I make a habit to watch as many first-episodes as I can).
It was just like, "You know that episode of Quantum Leap where Sam goes back and tries to save Kennedy? What if EVERY episode was like that?" -- the creators of Timeless never understood that it was personal moments and self-redemption that made QL a success... not "famous people from history".
Given that official box art covers have never referred to episodes 1 - 3 as "prequels", I'm certain this is fan-made.

Timeless was *finally* starting to become interesting, too - but I had this pegged as a one-and-done from the outset. Too bad, there was some actual potential here. (Network) TV hasn't has a good time-travel show since "Journeyman", which also didn't make it past s1.

Right, that's what I said - you needed to be partnered (with YouTube). But that isn't the same thing as joining a network.
You don't need to join a network to become a partner. You can do that directly with YouTube. How did you think the process existed before MCNs were around?

That's why, whenever Zombie Paul Walker was in Fast 7 (nearly half his shots), they always tried to obscure his face behind glass, through a debris field, or just have him slightly out of focus in the background. Shots NEVER lingered longer than necessary.

True-View banners are per-click. Pre/Post-rolls are per view; classified in analytics as "monetized views".
This is all in the YouTube help-pages and documentation.

wanted to join a network so that I could do my own thumbnails,
Lol, what? Custom thumbnails pre-date MCNs by like 3 years. There was *never* a period where you *had* to join one to get that benefit...

If I could have that ability without them i'd drop them.
You can! If your content is legitimately being re-uploaded so frequently, contact YouTube Partner Support, and request access to your own CMS account. That's how I became the owner of my only little independent MCN back in 2010. Now I can protect my content without forfeiting any revenue.
No.

AFAIK - your underhanded assumption is correct; self-age-restricting a video (which you'd normally never want to do) would effectively remove any ads on the content, for your, or any 3rd-party claimants.
Both. Depends on the ad-type.
2004 ALCS all other sports comebacks, last night's amazing SB win included.
Why don't you try Google Analytics? Pretty sure they include CRT-numbers. Just gotta link your YouTube page to Google first.
... a higher quality version, I hope?

I started a series of side-channels, and through evidence of mass-theft, convinced YouTube I needed access to the Content ID tools to help protect my growing brand. This was back in 2010 though - no idea if they even award individual CMS accounts anymore.
I was referring to a "second channel", that runs concurrently with your original one - not a new/replacement channel.
See my other reply here :-)

That I shouldn't have started another one, haha.
Fracturing my audience when I was doing well helped protect the 'brand' - but it just diluted my viewership across different channels.

* Music - https://www.reddit.com/r/letsplay/comments/3lxa50/100_free_music_sources_for_your_videos_list/
As for sponsors? You want to wait until they start to approach you. Or, build up some ad-friendly (PG-rated) material in the genre you're interested in selling ad-space to, and then make some pitches on Famebit. Even if you're only pulling in like 1,000 views a video, you can land $100 - $300 contracts for product reviews, shout-outs, product-placement, etc.
Eventually, Ford might [give you a free car](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5nRy8jU4OGI)!

I didn't start actively applying (and even then, only via Famebit, and only once or twice a month) until a couple years ago. 90% of my best deals come from unsolicited offers from the brands / sponsors themselves.
When you're large enough, they'll reach out to you. Just make sure your business e-mail is easily accessible.

YouTuber with 1mil+ subs here: **they're all shit. Stay independent.** If you need help with copyright / Content ID issues, talk to me - a MCN won't be able to assist you there. If you need royalty free music or assets, I can share some links. If you need help acquiring sponsors, I've worked with over 30, and could share some tips. There's literally nothing they can offer that you can't get for yourself. Unless you're able to negotiate a really favorable percentage with an off-setting signing bonus, don't bother with any network.
I've been with Maker, Discovery, and now - part of my own CMS. -- stay where you are, trust me :-)

*Star Trek* meets *Timeless*.
I've had this idea myself - and I think there are ways to make it interesting, and maintain tension. I think longer arcs in certain time-periods would help, as well as stretches of episodes where they *don't* time travel. That being said, I agree with others here - it'd be difficult to truly sustain interest, or fill the show with any sense of 'wonder'.
I loved Quantum Leap though, and I think keeping the temporal jumps to smaller-scale, person/ship-specific incidents (instead of saving entire planets, for example) would be really fascinating. And obviously, any time-jumps that took place within the short timeline of the show itself (going back to their own pilot) could be really neat.

WRITING.TITLE: This Brazilian on Twitter correctly guessed the "half-assed" title two weeks ago.

WRITING.TEXT:
Hmm - interesting plugin you have there, didn't know it was possible to see who owns the claim.
It's entirely possible that they had a claim, fought it, and won. Or, since they're a managed channel, it is possible they weren't hit with it at all. Evidence here is spotty, but as far as I know - managed channels are only immune to automatic scans on upload. They can still be tagged by claims afterwards by both an automated search, or manual tagging. I know, because I was managed with Maker Studios, and now own my own independent MCN.
I don't know that it qualifies as a double standard though. The channels that are managed have proven themselves in many ways, and YouTube, and/or their respective networks know that they are able to be trusted.
In the meantime, if you have a LEGITIMATE fair use to a piece of copyrighted material, never be afraid to dispute *and* appeal, *and* counter-notify. Most people get scared, and give up after the first step, and then bitch that the system doesn't work. You can't give up after the first period in a hockey game.

with seemingly no recourse
How do you know they aren't hit with claims constantly? Their work is fair use, so they probably just dispute the claims as they get them.
I'd recommend watching my video on [Content ID](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slgldWAsB0M) - it'll explain everything you seem confused about.
Don't be afraid to do film reviews though; I've uploaded more 3rd-party copyrighted material to my channels than *probably* anyone else on all of YouTube, and I'm happy to report that I still have a 100% win-rate with the 2,000+ claims I've received over the years.

Based on episode 1's "next week on" preview - it seems like Lee and Hilmar are taunting the cops; which means they prepared, and they'll go far. Not sure I actually want to watch every episode (because the show is objectively quite bad) - but it might become my next guilty pleasure...
The fuck didn't ANY of the "fugitives" have go-bags prepared? I'm neither a criminal, nor a frequent traveler, and I always have a bag 80% packed and ready to go.

I see a few solutions:
1. Switch from a VBR to a one-pass CBR, around 8mb/s. 1. Render at 720p instead. 1. Queue multiple videos into the Adobe Media Encoder, and render/export them overnight. 1. Upgrade your GPU to a Mercury Playback Engine compatible card.
Then your original question is totally moot. You're not creating content for 'different audiences' - it's all the exact same audience; gamers.
Um, no? My channels predate that silly nonsense. www.YouTube.com/Jogwheel absolutely works - I know because I had them set up the redirect myself :-)

... those videos all sound exactly the same, haha. You'll be fine.
I mix travel vlogs with political rants with SNES let's plays, and my audience doesn't seem to mind. Do whatever you want, but try to keep it consistent.

I've been doing YouTube as a full-time career for nine years now, and I'm *STILL* figuring out how to make, and keep it viable. There's no magic solution - just make money and deals whenever / wherever you can. Supplement AdSense with sponsorships, affiliate programs, 3rd-party content aggregators, and other companies that'll license your footage. Having some freelance work on the side is a good idea, though.
Anything above 5% is pretty good, actually.

If you can't get to 1,000 on your own - you're likely not creating anything worth highlighting on the main page anyway.
The truth hurts sometimes.
Dead subs are worse, trust me on this one.
